utterances: Anytime.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
Im Neal Conan in Washington.
O'SHEA: What free shipping does is, it can cement the relationship with the customer.
It can help you make a sale.
And hopefully, there's something additive at some point in that relationship that allows you to recoup the cost of that free shipping.

O'Shea says some big retailers, like Walmart, Target and Best Buy, are well-positioned to absorb those free shipping costs because they already have a complete supply chain in place to feed their many brick and mortar stores, which can also serve as pickup locations or even last-mile delivery hubs.

He estimates that shipping will cost Amazon close to $15 billion this year with only some of that offset by Prime memberships, but the online retail giant seems willing to take the hit in order to expand its market share.
But other retailers with slumping store sales can't afford to lose more money on free shipping, especially, O'Shea says, as that arms race escalates to two-day, next-day and even same-day delivery.
O'SHEA: And with any arms race, at some point you're overshooting.
As for those of us online shoppers who think we're not paying for delivery, well, think again.
There's no such thing as free shipping.
There's also no free lunch.
O'SHEA: That's Anne Goodchild of the University of Washington Supply Chain Transportation and Logistics Center.

She says even though we might be staying home and shopping online instead of driving to the mall, that one trip to the mall for six or eight things might now be replaced by six or eight different trucks delivering to our home.
My informed opinion, based on having conducted research in this area, is that we're increasing traffic.
In addition to worsening congestion, Goodchild says our radical change in shopping habits is taking a toll on roadways and bridges not really designed for the e-commerce boom.
It's a struggle, and we're behind in terms of having the infrastructure catch up to how it's being used so differently.
And that's just for having all of our goods shipped to us.
Already, the holiday delivery supply chain is shifting gears into reverse for the rush of returns of all those things we purchased online that either don't fit or we don't want.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
Two big international elections over the weekend and a split decision for the leaders involved.
In Russia, President Vladimir Putin's party won parliamentary elections, but in Venezuela voters gave President Hugo Chavez an unprecedented defeat.
They said no to constitutional changes that would have given him greater powers.
President Chavez's reaction to the loss?
He accepted defeat quickly and said in an announcement those who thought I would not accept this, you can go home and quietly celebrate.
We're joined by NPR's Juan Forero in Caracas.
Hi, Juan.
What is the mood in Venezuela today, the day after the election, as the news spreads that Mr. Chavez lost?
Well, there's joy on the opposition side.
They've lost one election after another since Chavez was first elected in 1988, and all those losses have been big.
The no vote felt that this election was crucial.
A yes vote to them would have given the president extraordinary powers, and they felt that it would have phased out whatever checks and balances exist here.
On the government side, of course, the vote was a letdown, for many of the same reasons.
They wanted to give Chavez more power, and a yes vote was considered important to consolidate the president's Bolivarian revolution, as he calls it.
Let's note that the margin of defeat was very, very close.
It's a 51-49 referendum.
It was very, very tight.
But it was hard for the president because he won reelection in December of last year by well over 20 points.
Now, President Chavez says, okay, I accept defeat on this, but he also said I'm not going to give up on these constitutional changes that I want.
So what are his options at this point?
The president said that his consolidation of his revolution continues, but he didn't really provide many details.
Some analysts have said that the government could push for an elected constituent assembly to rewrite the constitution, but that is a bigger lift than a referendum, much bigger.
And Chavez clearly doesn't have that kind of support right now.
So what are the changes that he wants in this referendum exactly?
Remind us of those.
The reforms would have included a whole bunch of unpopular measures like indefinite reelection for the president, increasing the presidential term from six to seven years.
Chavez also would've been able to create provinces and named governors and mayors, and he would've had control - complete control of the central bank and the government's revenues.
There were some sweeteners for voters, like he offered pensions for informal sector workers, but it just wasn't enough to sway Venezuelans.
Juan, what are you reading in the papers and hearing there on the streets and from broadcasts for Venezuelan analysis about why he lost this?
I mean he's had a lot of support, as you mentioned earlier.
Well, one of the biggest reasons is that the election was not about the president; it was about the reforms.
They may like the president, but they didn't want to give him the right to seek reelection for the rest of his life.
That was a huge thing.
The other thing was that there were a number of people who turned against him, who had been close to him, people who were very prominent, and who had been with him for many, many years.
And when they turned against it publicly, that really gave momentum to the opposition.
Chavez tried to cast the vote as a plebiscite on his rule.
He even went so far as to say that a vote for the no camp would be the same as voting for George Bush, who's not popular in this country.
Nevertheless, it just didn't work.
You mentioned President Bush.
Has the State Department said anything about this yet?
Yeah, exactly, for a friend.
So how can you make this kind of exciting for kids to say - I mean, maybe not the real little ones, but the ones who are basically expecting a video game?
Were you - I mean, I imagine if I were in that situation, I would have been furious.
Well, yeah, the United States said that this was a vote to preserve democracy.
The U.S.
Undersecretary of State Nicholas Burns told reporters that the U.S.
government felt that the referendum would've made President Chavez the president for life.
He said that the country really wants to remain a democracy and that the people had spoken.
So the United States was very pleased by the outcome.
NPR's Juan Forero in Caracas, Venezuela.
Juan, Thank you.
Thank you.

Kids' book author Jon Scieszka believes.

I was more honestly the fan of, like, the crazy.

...Guys like Dr. Seuss, P.D.
Eastman.

No.
...Stealing hats.
(LAUGHTER)
That's my idea of a book.
I think maybe because it was, like, my family of five or six boys all together.
I guess five brothers - doing the math here in my head.
You mentioned P.D.
Eastman.
And I know this is a book you do think about, ""Go, Dog.
Go!"" Tell us about that, why you think it's a holiday must.
Oh, that is just one of my favorites forever.
I think this was one of those books that got me reading.
And it was published in 1961.
Yep.
And it's so much fun.
It's actually, like, I think a zen koan or, like, a meditation on just being present.
So the first three pages, the entire text is dog, big dog, little dog.
And that's exactly what it shows.
It's so satisfying.
I mean, there's a red dog on a blue tree, a blue dog on a red tree.
It's just - that's what you see.
It's so much fun.
And then a giant party up in a tree - so you can't go wrong with something like that.
